ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: learned how to work on and think about long poems; multimedia poetry

This class was truly one of the best classes I've taken at Yale. I learned about the art of poetry writing, of course, but I also learned about what it means to be writer, a reader, and a general person who cares about the world. I was introduced to so many new artists who I am eager to continue learning from.
I learned about the logic or mathematics of writing a poem. I learned to trust my voice as a poet and spend time studying poets like me.
taking risks with language, arithmetic of world-building in poetry, process of revision, multi-media forms for poetic expression
I learned how to think critically about the poetry I read and write. I learned how to verbalize my thoughts about a poem. I learned how techniques for editing my own poetry.
I learned to analyze the work of other and provide them helpful feedback, and also to carefully analyze my own poetry, particularly on the level of lineation.
I learned key skills in editing poems for form, content, and style.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: poetry writing seminars are, of course, always best in person.

I thought this course was excellent. WhileI loved how the focus was on two major poetry sequences that I really had to commit to, I wish we could have done a few more smaller writing exercises in class to get warmed up. The reading list was outstanding.
Everything was great. Professor Rankine and Emily provided insightful feedback.

Strengths: directed and diverse readings that cater to a specific prompt. Really amazing feedback from both Professor Rankine and Professor Skillings often with actionable advice.
Weaknesses: I think Professor Rankine wanted to facilitate more natural discussion with mics unmuted, but somehow the act of muting is so normalized that I think the recommendation to unmute made discussions feel difficult.

This was a strong poetry workshop, allowing students to gain insight on their own work from the perspectives of other poets as well as themselves. The course could be strengthened by a closer focus on the theme/themes of the course, and perhaps a selection of less expansive themes.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: great use of discussion board on canvas
I thought this course was successful over Zoom, especially because many of us kept our camera and mic on!
Raise hand feature might be helpful for zoom-based conversations.
It was difficult to recreate the experience of a poetry workshop over zoom, but the professors used helpful methods, such as breakout rooms, to recreate the atmosphere of a normal workshop.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Incredible opportunity to read, write, and discuss poetry with brilliant poets and peers.
I would absolutely recommend this to anyone who loves to read and to learn!

Yes. One thing I loved about this class was that the curriculum included not only poetry, but other works of literature, and we engaged with visual pieces in class. This approach provided a diverse source of inspiration and made me consider poetics as something that lives within different fields.
Yes!
Yes! I learned so much from this class not only about my own writing but about poets that I want to learn more from in the future. Professor Rankine and Professor Skillings are absolutely amazing.
YES!!!
Yes - I thought this was a wonderful opportunity to interact with a very insightful voice in the contemporary poetry landscape.
Yes, this I wish Claudia wasn't leaving she is amazing and works really well together with Emily.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Conferences outside of class
